channel.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
channel.description:
So, I'm trying to do some bug fixes on my server, and I'm trying to find a position for an object, instead of making it check for the name of it. (The object is a closed chest)
I think it might be something like
[code] new GameObject(2869, 2898, 9873, 0, 0, 10, 2868, 15, false);[/code]
But I'm not sure.

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sorecheeny sorecheeny
item.description:
@sorecheeny wrote:

It’s all good, I resolved this by adding ints to the ThieveOther class and the WalkToActionHandler class.

Thanks

Read full topic
item.source: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sorecheeny, post:5, topic:541265”]Alright, it’s in WalkToActionHandler.java , pretty much everything for clicking objects and such.

public static void doObjectSecondClick(final Player player) { final int id = player.getClickId(); final int x = player.getClickX(); final int y = player.getClickY(); final int z = player.getClickZ(); final int task = player.getTask();[/quote]
There’s more than one packet for this.
The one you are showing me is this one (Walk on command), there’s no wiki page for it though.
You want the click object packet in it’s entirety, since that packet should be sent after the walk on command (If I remember correctly)

Read full topic

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sorecheeny sorecheeny
item.description:
@sorecheeny wrote:

Alright, it’s in WalkToActionHandler.java , pretty much everything for clicking objects and such.

public static void doObjectSecondClick(final Player player) { final int id = player.getClickId(); final int x = player.getClickX(); final int y = player.getClickY(); final int z = player.getClickZ(); final int task = player.getTask();

Read full topic
item.source: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“sorecheeny, post:3, topic:541265”]Well, here’s a case of opening a cupboard, it changing the GameObject to an open cupboard, and sending a message in ActionSender:

case 2868: new GameObject(2869, 2898, 9873, 0, 0, 10, 2868, 15, false); player.getActionSender().sendMessage("You open the cupboard."); player.getUpdateFlags().sendAnimation(832); break;

I think I might have got the general idea actually.[/quote]
So from looking at that. 2869 looks like the new object, 2898 would probably be the X, 9873 the Y, one of the 0’s is rotation, don’t know the other, 10 is object type, 2868 is previous, 15 is idk (probably timer), and false idk. If you looked in the game object class I’m sure it’d say.

Show me the method you’re putting this case in, the method in ActionSender. I’m sure it has everything handled you’re just not calling it.

Read full topic
item.source: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sorecheeny sorecheeny
item.description:
@sorecheeny wrote:

Well, here’s a case of opening a cupboard, it changing the GameObject to an open cupboard, and sending a message in ActionSender:

case 2868: new GameObject(2869, 2898, 9873, 0, 0, 10, 2868, 15, false); player.getActionSender().sendMessage("You open the cupboard."); player.getUpdateFlags().sendAnimation(832); break;

I think I might have got the general idea actually.

Read full topic

item.title: RUNESOURCE - Checking an object's position to make it do things
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Your Object clicking packet should honestly already handle the X, Y, and objectId.

I haven’t used RuneSource, but look in your packets.
